newsitem.title: USA: INTERVIEW - Cold Metal Products sees net up.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW - Cold Metal Products sees net up.

text.p: Profitability at Cold Metal Products Inc should improve over the next several quarters as the company's new steel rolling facility increases production and eliminates start-up problems, the company's president and chief executive officer said Thursday.
"We're convinced we've built the low cost, high quality facility we set out to build," James Harpster told Reuters in a phone interview.

The new $25 million plant in Ottawa, Ohio, was hit by start-up delays last year, which has dampened earnings in recent months. The facility, originally slated for start-up in October '96, did not begin production until January.
Cold Metal Products earned $0.07 per share in its fiscal first quarter ended June 30 versus earnings of $0.20 per share a year ago.
Harpster, a 49 year-old executive who has been at the company's helm for more than a decade, said problems at the facility have been eliminated and that will boost earnings.

He said Wall Street estimates for the fiscal second quarter and fiscal '98 were "very conservative." The consensus is $0.05 for the quarter and $0.45 for the year. Earnings were $0.14 in last year's quarter and $0.47 in fiscal '97.

Cold Metal Products, based in Youngstown, Ohio, is one of the country's largest steel processors, with nine plants in operation in North America. The company performs a number of operations including cold-rolling, annealing, and slitting, all of which add value to steel products.

The company buys steel from steel producers, processes it for customers, and resells it. It also performs toll processing, meaning it does not take ownership of steel inventory and charges a customer for processing services.
Harpster said the Ottawa facility has been steadily increasing production levels since January and should reach its processing capacity of 100,000 tons annually in the next couple of years.
Harpster said Cold Metal Products was in an expansion mode last year, purchasing a steel service center and a processing operation and building the Ottawa facility.
He said the company this year will turn somewhat inward, focusing on getting a satisfactory return on those investments.

"While acquisitions will be a part of our future, we're building a house on top of these foundations," he said. "The focus for this fiscal year will be getting a decent return out of the money we've invested."
Commenting on the current steel market, Harpster said steel prices have softened slightly, which should help buoy margins at his company.
"Volume is good and we think it will continue to be over the next few quarters," he said. "As far as the steel we buy, there has been a slight decrease in pricing.

"I think what's making things go down, is some of this new capacity is starting to come in place," he said, referring to the spate of new steel minimills either under construction or in production in North America.
While steel producers like to see prices rise, softening prices can be beneficial for steel processors, who have to buy the steel for resale.

"When prices were higher (last year) we were not able to pass all of that through to our customers," Harpster said. "As a result we saw a squeeze on margins...(softening prices) should help that margin squeeze a little bit."
